ABBREVIATIONS

WTO    –  World Trade Organization 
 
 
NOTES 
 
(i)  The fiscal year of the Government ends on 31 December. 
(ii)  In this report, “$” refers to US dollars.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested assistance of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB), during the 2000 country programming mission, to support the 
People’s Bank of China (PBC) in strengthening the financial sector. Amid rapid development of 
the  PRC  financial  sector,  bringing  its  legal  and  regulatory  framework  up  to  international 
standards is critical for better integration of the market with the global financial market. Laws 
and regulations need to be streamlined under a systematic banking oversight framework, those 
that are clearly in conflict with the development of the financial sector should be reviewed, 
removed and amended to be consistent with the World Trade Organization (WTO) framework, 
and  new  laws  and  regulations  need  to  be  drafted  to  tackle  challenging  issues  facing  the 
financial sector. Fact-finding missions visited the PRC in March 2001 and March 2002 to reach 
an understanding with PBC and the Government on the objectives, scope, cost, financing, and 
implementation arrangements for the technical assistance (TA).1 The TA framework is provided 
in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The PRC’s financial sector is now governed by the PBC Law, Commercial Banking Law, 
Negotiable  Instruments  Law,  Insurance  Law,  Securities  Law,  Trust  Law,  and  significant 
subordinate  legislation  such  as  regulations,  decrees,  provisions,  and  opinions  issued  by 
different agencies. Under the PBC Law, effective in March 1995, PBC is entrusted with the 
responsibility to (i) formulate and implement monetary policy; (ii) exercise supervision and 
administration of the financial industry; and (iii) examine and approve the establishment of PRC 
financial institutions, including those with foreign investment and branch offices of foreign banks. 
The PBC Law also prohibits PBC from lending to government authorities. 
 
3.  The Commercial Banking Law, effective in July 1995, standardized the commercial 
behavior of banks, which were mostly state-owned. Under the law, commercial banks need to 
be established in accordance with legal requirements under the Company Law of 1994. Banks 
are required to be formed as limited liability companies and acquire the status of a legal person 
responsible for their own liabilities and debts to the extent of their assets. The law also sets out 
the  general  principles  for  lending,  personnel  management,  and  depositor  protection.  The 
commercial banks established prior to the enactment of the Commercial Banking Law are 
provided with lead time to reorganize their structures to comply with the Company Law. The 
Negotiable  Instruments  Law,  effective  in  January  1996,  applies  to  bills  of  exchanges, 
promissory notes, and checks, and specifies the liabilities arising under these instruments. 
 
4.  The Securities Law of July 1999 provides regulatory and supervisory authority to the 
China Securities Regulatory Commission over the issuing and trading of securities, take over of 
listed companies and over securities firms, securities exchanges, central depositories, clearing 
institutions, investment banks, and credit-rating agencies. The Insurance Law of October 1995 
specifies the requirements for setting up an insurance company for the formation of insurance 
contracts. PBC was entrusted with the regulatory and supervisory responsibility of the insurance 
industry when the law was enacted. However, in late 1998, responsibility for oversight of the 
insurance sector was transferred to the China Insurance Regulatory Commission. Currently, 
regulations in various forms are still being drafted to expand and clarify the Insurance Law. The 
Trust Law effective on 1 October 2001 lays down the foundation for developing legal trusts in 
the  PRC  and  defines  fiduciary  duties  and  imposes  rules  governing  boards  of  trustees.  In

addition to the basic Trust Law, the Government sees the need to prepare detailed rules for 
specific trusts, such as pension and investment funds.  
 
5.  Supported  by  the  World  Bank’s  supervisory  project  in  1996,  PBC  drafted  a  set  of 
banking regulations defining (i) the purpose and scope of regulatory activities, administrative 
authority and procedures, and organization of the PBC; and (ii) organization, expansion, and 
corporate activities of a commercial bank. Regulations have been introduced to define the 
scope of permitted bank business (deposit taking, borrowing, lending, investment, real estate, 
trading  activities),  capital  requirements,  liquidity  and  interest  rate  risk  management 
requirements,  payments  and  settlements  operations,  operational  requirements  and  internal 
controls, prudential reporting requirements, administrative remedies, examination authority of 
the PBC, takeover of a commercial bank by the PBC, and resolution of troubled banks. PBC has 
developed an outline of a banking manual that could be distributed to commercial banks that 
would include all relevant PBC laws and regulations, updated on a regular basis. 
 
6.  The promulgation of these financial sector laws accelerated the reform and growth of 
both the banking and nonbanking subsectors. Despite this progress, the PRC financial market is 
still governed by a series of low-level and sometimes conflicting legislation. The current process 
of preparing laws and regulations is seen as ad hoc, lacking pro-active approaches that would 
streamline  laws  and  regulations  under  a  systematic  banking  system  oversight  framework. 
Investors not familiar with the legal and regulatory systems need to consult several sets of rules 
and regulations to conduct financial sector operations effectively. Finally, no consistent and 
effective  approach  is  used  to  enact  and  amend  laws  and  regulations,  and  transparent 
procedures are not available to involve stakeholders in the legislation process.  
 
7.  Since the late 1990s, the PRC has experienced the failure of trusts and investment 
companies.  To  strengthen  the  regulatory  framework  and  supervisory  system,  the  PRC 
introduced strict segregation of banking, securities, and insurance businesses. As a result, a 
segregated  regulatory  framework  identifies  the  PBC  as  the  banking  regulator,  the  China 
Securities Regulatory Commission as the capital markets regulator, and the China Insurance 
Regulatory Commission as the insurance market regulator. Strict segregation can be effective in 
enforcing market discipline and prudence of financial institutions particularly in less-developed 
market environments such as the PRC. However it has introduced an inherent risk of regulatory 
gaps and forgoes opportunities of financial service consolidation that capitalizes on economy of 
scale, operational efficiency, and a broader customer base. Regulatory segregation has not 
stopped conglomeration of financial services in the PRC. A number of holding companies (e.g., 
China  International  Trust  and  Investment  Company,  China  Everbright  Group,  and  China 
Merchant Group) are engaged in banking, insurance, and securities businesses; banks (e.g., 
Bank  of  China)  in  securities;  and  insurance  companies  in  fund  management.  Prudential 
supervision proves to be more difficult in a segregated system where financial institutions are 
engaged in cross-sector activities.2 The PBC has no mechanism to address solvency issues 
within  a  financial  conglomerate  such  as  double  or  multiple  gearing,  risks  incurred  by 
unregulated entities, and erection of firewalls between subsidiaries and between subsidiaries 
and parent companies. 
 
8.  The failure of trust and investment companies also exposes the weakness of bankruptcy 
legislation in the PRC. Bankruptcy of financial institutions is governed by the 1986 Bankruptcy 
Law for state-owned enterprises and the provisional regulations for financial institutions issued 
                                                 
2  Some efforts have been made to set up an interagency committee among regulators to improve coordination.

3 
by PBC in 1994. The law does not provide any clear trigger for bankruptcy or rehabilitation or 
stipulation for creditor’s rights and protection of depositors. 
 
9.  The need for anti-money laundering efforts has become a pressing issue for the PRC’s 
financial sector following economic liberalization and opening up to the outside world. The 1997 
amendment of the Criminal Law criminalized money laundering for the first time. However, the 
relevant clauses define “upstream crimes” rather narrowly and cover only three types of crimes, 
namely money from narcotics crimes, organized crimes of the underworld, and smuggling. The 
2001 amendment of the Criminal Law added terrorism as another type of upstream crime. 
However, it still does not cover illegal incomes from corruption and other economic crimes, does 
not provide corresponding financial regulations, and does not provide a mechanism to work with 
foreign regulatory authorities. PBC plans to work with domestic law enforcement agencies, 
customs, tax bureau, other financial market regulators, and foreign governments to strengthen 
the legal and regulatory system against money laundering. 
 
10.  The Government recognizes the importance of a credit reporting system to facilitate 
financing of small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and development of consumer banking 
services. A well-designed and managed system can be used to track those that do not pay and 
those that honor their obligations as well as keep records on employment and legal actions filed 
against enterprises and individuals. Credit reporting provides significant benefits to the financial 
system and the economy, including allowing SMEs and individual consumers with good credit to 
open and expand credit lines; providing banks with reliable data for making sound judgments 
about credit; reducing loan losses and bankruptcies through more accurate and cost-efficient 
assessment; and preventing fraud by tracking credit habits of enterprises and individuals so that 
a sudden buildup of credit far beyond the repayment ability of the debtor can be recognized. A 
set of principles and standards should be developed and placed in regulations and policies to 
govern the development of such a system. It is in the interest of government that all credit 
grantors participate in the credit reporting system to improve the quality of credit being extended 
and to encourage increased SME lending through improved information to financial institutions. 
Regulation will be needed to provide access of credit providers to information, and at the same 
time protect individuals and companies from misuse of the system by credit providers.  
 
11.  The PRC has made far-reaching commitments in WTO negotiations to open up its 
financial sector. During the phase-out period of 5 years, the PRC will gradually remove the 
geographic and legal restrictions for foreign financial institutions and liberalize the scope of 
businesses. The final commitments will open the sector to foreign access while maintaining 
some limitation on cross-border supply and scope of business and foreign equity involvement. 
Foreign  participation  in  the  PRC  financial  sector  has  been  governed  by  separate  sets  of 
temporary regulations and provisions. However, the PRC’s entry into WTO requires a complete 
overhaul  of  these  temporary  regulations  to  make  them  consistent  with  the  PRC’s  WTO 
commitment regarding opening up the financial industry. PBC has to improve the legal and 
regulatory system to address existing weaknesses and be ready for future challenges. PBC will 
need to identify legislation that is clearly in conflict with the development of the financial sector, 
amend legislation that needs to be consistent with the PRC’s WTO commitment, and draft 
legislation to tackle new issues facing the financial sector.  
 
12.  ADB’s strategy in the financial sector is to support the Government’s efforts to establish 
a progressive policy and institutional framework, improve the legal and regulatory environment, 
facilitate its complete integration into the global financial market, and enable the financial sector 
to play an important role in the PRC’s transition to a market economy. The assistance for the 
development of the enabling legal and regulatory environment is an essential area for improving

4 
institutional capability, transparency, and governance of the PRC financial sector. Since 1987, 
ADB has supported capacity building for the banking system and strengthening of the legal and 
regulatory framework in the PRC.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
13.  The objectives of the TA are to assist PBC to strengthen the legal and regulatory 
framework for the banking system, in particular, to streamline laws and regulations under a 
systematic banking oversight framework, identify legislation that is clearly in conflict with the 
development of the financial sector, and amend legislation that needs to be consistent with the 
PRC’s WTO commitments. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
14.  The scope of the TA includes 
 
(i)  developing a consistent approach for achieving a systematic and forward-looking 
banking legislative and regulation framework by analyzing weaknesses of the 
existing  PRC  banking  laws  and  regulations,  clarify  issues  that  need  to  be 
addressed, identify key driving factors, establish a direction for future legislative 
and regulatory work, and develop a legislative plan to be consistent with the 
overall framework; 
 
(ii)  assisting PBC to draft a set of laws and regulations including regulations on 
credit information bureau, bankruptcy code for financial institutions, measures 
governing financial conglomerates, and laws against financial crimes such as 
money laundering; 
 
(iii)  examining inconsistencies of existing financial sector laws and regulations with 
the PRC’s WTO commitments, identify areas that need immediate action, and 
recommend means for proper legal and regulatory treatments both for the phase-
out period of 3 to 5 years and for the final commitment;  
 
(iv)  evaluating the feasibility and advising the PBC on how to address the issues 
brought  by  the  segregated  regulatory  system  and  how  to  properly  regulate 
financial conglomerates particularly from the prudential regulation point of view; 
and 
 
(v)  developing case studies to demonstrate and train PBC legal staff on how to 
identify legal and regulatory issues, adopt consistent and effective approaches, 
ensure stakeholders’ participation, and be consistent with the overall legislative 
framework of the financial sector. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $1,000,000 equivalent. ADB will finance 
$800,000 equivalent on a grant basis from the ADB-funded TA Program, including the entire 
foreign  exchange  cost  of  $635,000  and  local  currency  cost  of  $165,000  equivalent.  The

5 
Government will provide $200,000 equivalent through the provision of counterpart staff, office 
space, and contingencies. Details of the cost estimates are provided in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  PBC will be the Executing Agency. The Legal Department of PBC will be responsible for 
TA implementation. A working group will be established, under the leadership of the director 
general of the Legal Department, to work as counterparts to the respective consultants and 
ensure successful TA implementation. The working group is also responsible for coordination of 
other concerned agencies on interrelated issues. PBC will provide the necessary office space, 
counterpart  staff,  transportation,  and  other  services  to  the  consultants,  and  will  arrange 
appointments for the consultants with relevant agencies and organizations.  
 
17.  The TA will engage a team of international consultants for a total of 14 person-months: 
one banking regulatory expert and team leader who has practical experience with legal and 
regulatory  treatment  of  banking  issues;  one  WTO  expert  who  understands  the  legal  and 
regulatory implications of the PRC’s WTO commitments; and a number of banking legal experts 
to assist PBC to draft various laws and regulations. A team of domestic consultants for a total of 
14 person-months will have the same set of expertise as the international consultants. The 
terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. The consultants will be selected and 
engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other 
arrangements on the selection and engagement of domestic consultants. Country experience 
and knowledge will be taken into account in selecting the consultants. In view of the specific and 
detailed nature of TA terms of reference, the simplified technical proposal format will be used. 
 
18.  The team leader will be responsible for the delivery of reports. The consultants will 
submit  (i)  an  inception  report  3  weeks  after  commencement  of  their  services,  (ii)  interim 
progress reports at appropriate stages of TA implementation, (iii) a draft final report before the 
conclusion of the contract, and (iv) a final report 2 weeks after incorporating PBC’s and ADB's 
comments. The TA will commence in July 2002 and be completed in June 2003. Seminars and 
workshops  will  be  organized  intermittently  during  implementation  to  invite  comments  from 
international and domestic experts in the field and disseminate the findings of the report.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Banking Laws and Regulations, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants (14 person-months) 
 
1.  Team Leader and Banking Regulatory Expert (4 person-months) 
 
1.  The expert will be responsible for the overall management of technical assistance (TA) 
implementation and the timely delivery of good quality interim and final reports The expert will 
be primarily responsible for assisting People’s Bank of China (PBC) staff with specific laws and 
regulation and organizing training activities. Specifically, the expert will 
 
(i)  assist PBC to set up an inventory of financial sector laws and regulations and 
explore the best ways to categorize the inventory and identify strengths and 
weaknesses of existing framework; 
 
(ii)  clarify issues that need to be addressed, identify key driving factors, establish a 
direction for future legislative and regulatory work, and develop a plan that leads 
to the establishment of a forward-looking framework; 
 
(iii)  use the opportunity of working on specific laws and regulations with PBC staff as 
real case studies to demonstrate and train PBC staff on how to define legal and 
regulatory issues, and how to maintain consistency with the overall legislative 
framework when drafting individual pieces of legislation and regulations; and 
 
(iv)  design  corresponding  training  activities;  introduce  legislative  and  regulatory 
framework of foreign countries with advanced financial markets; and based on 
experiences  of  foreign  countries,  recommend  measures  to  improve  the 
consistency, effectiveness, transparency, and level of stakeholder participation in 
the legislation process.  
 
2.  World Trade Organization Expert (4 person-months) 
 
2.  The expert will be primarily responsible for analyzing the existing financial sector legal 
and  regulatory  system  against  the  World  Trade  Organization  (WTO)  commitments  of  the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC) upon the accession.  Specifically, the expert will 
 
(i)  review the commitments made by the PRC during WTO negotiations pertaining 
to  banking,  securities,  and  insurance;  examine  inconsistencies  of  existing 
financial sector laws and regulations; and identify areas that need immediate 
action  to  make  the  legal  and  regulatory  system  consistent  with  WTO 
commitments, specifically, 
 
(a)  evaluate commitments during phase-out periods and final commitments in 
four modes of liberalization of market access under the framework of 
General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS), namely, cross-border 
supply,  consumption  abroad,  commercial  presence,  and  supply  of 
services through the presence of natural persons;  
 
(b)  evaluate schedules of achieving national treatment for each of the four 
models and possible limitations or additional commitments pertaining to 
such matters as qualifications, standards, and licensing;

Appendix 3  9 
 
(ii)  based on the overall legislative framework for the financial sector, recommend 
means  for  proper  legal  and  regulatory  treatments  for  the  PRC’s  WTO 
commitments in the financial sector both for the phase-out period of 5 years and 
for final commitment; and 
 
(iii)  work on real cases with PBC staff on amending and drafting specific laws and 
regulations as a mean of training PBC staff in handling complicated issues when 
working with legislation and regulations.  
 
3.  Banking Legal Experts (6 person-months) 
 
3.  The team of lawyers will be primarily responsible for assisting PBC legal staff to draft 
particular laws and regulations that require urgent attention; these include regulation on credit 
information bureau, and legislation governing financial conglomerates, anti-money laundering, 
and bankruptcy code for financial institutions, respectively. This team of lawyers needs to 
 
(i)  develop a set of principles and standards to govern the development of the credit 
information  system,  ensure  that  all  credit  grantors  participating  in  the  credit 
reporting system will improve the quality of credit being extended and encourage 
increased small and medium enterprises lending through improved information to 
financial institutions, grant access of credit providers to information and at the 
same  time  establish  safeguards  against  unauthorized  use  of  the  credit 
information, and protect individuals and companies from misuses; 
 
(ii)  review constraints and gaps of existing laws and regulations that are being used 
to  govern  financial  conglomerates,  introduce  the  principle  and  measurement 
techniques to facilitate the assessment of capital adequacy on a group-wide 
basis  for  heterogeneous  financial  conglomerates,  identify  situations  such  as 
double  or  multiple  gearing  under  the  existing  regulations  that  result  in  an 
overstatement  of  the  group’s  capital,  address  risks  being  accepted  by 
unregulated  entities  within  a  financial  conglomerate,  recommend  erection  of 
appropriate firewalls between subsidiaries and between subsidiaries and parent 
companies, and recommend an effective coordination mechanism with the China 
Securities Regulatory Commission and China Insurance Regulatory Commission; 
 
(iii)  recommend improvements in the country’s overall legal system to combat money 
laundering, including criminal law, financial institutional secrecy law, and law 
enforcement  capabilities;  adopt  measures  to  allow  authorities  to  confiscate 
property and levy monetary and civil penalties; strengthen financial institutions’ 
capability for customer identification, record keeping, and increased diligence; 
extend anti-money laundering measures to banking subsidiaries and international 
branches,  and  implement  feasible  measures  to  detect  physical  cross-border 
transportation  of  cash  and  negotiable  instruments;  and  equip  supervisory 
authorities  with  expertise  and  technical  know-how  to  guard  against  money 
laundering; and 
 
(iv)  identify areas of inapplicability of existing bankruptcy legislation in handling the 
bankruptcy of financial institutions and evaluate specific legal requirements for 
insolvent financial institutions, including issues related to avoidance of systemic 
crisis, containment, liquidity support, rehabilitation and restructuring of troubled

10  Appendix 3 
banks,  regulatory  forbearance,  recapitalization,  resolution  of  nonperforming 
assets, depositor protection, creation of special bankruptcy courts, and the use of 
specialized insolvency judges to ensure consistent application of the law, as well 
as out-of-court restructuring. 
 
B.  Domestic Consultants (14 person-months) 
 
4.  Domestic consultants will be recruited to assist the international consulting team. These 
consultants should have extensive in-depth local industry knowledge and good contacts in 
various areas of banking law and regulation. Domestic consultants will assist international 
consultants to quickly become familiarized with their tasks by translating various documents into 
English; researching and compiling a set of government policies, regulations, and procedures 
adopted; and ensuring the work by international consultants is appropriate to the PRC situation. 
Domestic consultants are expected to possess sufficient experience in their relevant fields, and 
will include a banking regulatory expert, WTO expert, and banking legal experts.
